description: Gets an Glue machine learning transform artifact and all its corresponding metadata. Machine learning transforms are a special type of transform that use machine learning to learn the details of the transformation to be performed by learning from examples provided by humans. These transformations are then saved by Glue. You can retrieve their metadata by calling GetMLTransform.

parameters.name: TransformId
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the transform, generated at the time that the transform was created.

nested_items.name: TransformId
nested_items.description: The unique identifier of the transform, generated at the time that the transform was created.

nested_items.name: Name
nested_items.description: The unique name given to the transform when it was created.

nested_items.name: Description
nested_items.description: A description of the transform.

nested_items.name: Status
nested_items.description: The last known status of the transform (to indicate whether it can be used or not). One of 'NOT_READY', 'READY', or 'DELETING'.

nested_items.name: CreatedOn
nested_items.description: The date and time when the transform was created.

nested_items.name: LastModifiedOn
nested_items.description: The date and time when the transform was last modified.

nested_items.name: InputRecordTables
nested_items.description: A list of Glue table definitions used by the transform.

nested_items.name: DatabaseName
nested_items.description: A database name in the Glue Data Catalog.

nested_items.name: TableName
nested_items.description: A table name in the Glue Data Catalog.

nested_items.name: CatalogId
nested_items.description: A unique identifier for the Glue Data Catalog.

nested_items.name: ConnectionName
nested_items.description: The name of the connection to the Glue Data Catalog.

nested_items.name: AdditionalOptions
nested_items.description: Additional options for the table. Currently there are two keys supported:
pushDownPredicate: to filter on partitions without having to list and read all the files in your dataset.
catalogPartitionPredicate: to use server-side partition pruning using partition indexes in the Glue Data Catalog.

nested_items.name: Parameters
nested_items.description: The configuration parameters that are specific to the algorithm used.

nested_items.name: TransformType
nested_items.description: The type of machine learning transform.

nested_items.name: FindMatchesParameters
nested_items.description: The parameters for the find matches algorithm.

nested_items.name: PrimaryKeyColumnName
nested_items.description: The name of a column that uniquely identifies rows in the source table. Used to help identify matching records.

nested_items.name: PrecisionRecallTradeoff
nested_items.description: The value selected when tuning your transform for a balance between precision and recall. A value of 0.5 means no preference; a value of 1.0 means a bias purely for precision, and a value of 0.0 means a bias for recall. Because this is a tradeoff, choosing values close to 1.0 means very low recall, and choosing values close to 0.0 results in very low precision.

nested_items.name: AccuracyCostTradeoff
nested_items.description: The value that is selected when tuning your transform for a balance between accuracy and cost. A value of 0.5 means that the system balances accuracy and cost concerns. A value of 1.0 means a bias purely for accuracy, which typically results in a higher cost, sometimes substantially higher. A value of 0.0 means a bias purely for cost, which results in a less accurate FindMatches transform, sometimes with unacceptable accuracy.

nested_items.name: EnforceProvidedLabels
nested_items.description: The value to switch on or off to force the output to match the provided labels from users. If the value is True, the find matches transform forces the output to match the provided labels. The results override the normal conflation results. If the value is False, the find matches transform does not ensure all the labels provided are respected, and the results rely on the trained model.

nested_items.name: EvaluationMetrics
nested_items.description: The latest evaluation metrics.

nested_items.name: TransformType
nested_items.description: The type of machine learning transform.

nested_items.name: FindMatchesMetrics
nested_items.description: The evaluation metrics for the find matches algorithm.

nested_items.name: AreaUnderPRCurve
nested_items.description: The area under the precision/recall curve (AUPRC) is a single number measuring the overall quality of the transform, that is independent of the choice made for precision vs. recall. Higher values indicate that you have a more attractive precision vs. recall tradeoff.

nested_items.name: Precision
nested_items.description: The precision metric indicates when often your transform is correct when it predicts a match. Specifically, it measures how well the transform finds true positives from the total true positives possible.

nested_items.name: Recall
nested_items.description: The recall metric indicates that for an actual match, how often your transform predicts the match. Specifically, it measures how well the transform finds true positives from the total records in the source data.

nested_items.name: F1
nested_items.description: The maximum F1 metric indicates the transform's accuracy between 0 and 1, where 1 is the best accuracy.

nested_items.name: ConfusionMatrix
nested_items.description: The confusion matrix shows you what your transform is predicting accurately and what types of errors it is making.

nested_items.name: NumTruePositives
nested_items.description: The number of matches in the data that the transform correctly found, in the confusion matrix for your transform.

nested_items.name: NumFalsePositives
nested_items.description: The number of nonmatches in the data that the transform incorrectly classified as a match, in the confusion matrix for your transform.

nested_items.name: NumTrueNegatives
nested_items.description: The number of nonmatches in the data that the transform correctly rejected, in the confusion matrix for your transform.

nested_items.name: NumFalseNegatives
nested_items.description: The number of matches in the data that the transform didn't find, in the confusion matrix for your transform.

nested_items.name: ColumnImportances
nested_items.description: A list of ColumnImportance structures containing column importance metrics, sorted in order of descending importance.

nested_items.name: ColumnName
nested_items.description: The name of a column.

nested_items.name: Importance
nested_items.description: The column importance score for the column, as a decimal.

nested_items.name: LabelCount
nested_items.description: The number of labels available for this transform.

nested_items.name: Schema
nested_items.description: The Map<Column, Type> object that represents the schema that this transform accepts. Has an upper bound of 100 columns.

nested_items.name: Name
nested_items.description: The name of the column.

nested_items.name: DataType
nested_items.description: The type of data in the column.

nested_items.name: Role
nested_items.description: The name or Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role with the required permissions.

nested_items.name: GlueVersion
nested_items.description: This value determines which version of Glue this machine learning transform is compatible with. Glue 1.0 is recommended for most customers. If the value is not set, the Glue compatibility defaults to Glue 0.9. For more information, see Glue Versions in the developer guide.

nested_items.name: MaxCapacity
nested_items.description: The number of Glue data processing units (DPUs) that are allocated to task runs for this transform. You can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the Glue pricing page.

nested_items.name: WorkerType
nested_items.description: The type of predefined worker that is allocated when this task runs. Accepts a value of Standard, G.1X, or G.2X.
For the Standard worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 50GB disk, and 2 executors per worker.
For the G.1X worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 64GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.
For the G.2X worker type, each worker provides 8 vCPU, 32 GB of memory and a 128GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

nested_items.name: NumberOfWorkers
nested_items.description: The number of workers of a defined workerType that are allocated when this task runs.

nested_items.name: Timeout
nested_items.description: The timeout for a task run for this transform in minutes. This is the maximum time that a task run for this transform can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours).

nested_items.name: MaxRetries
nested_items.description: The maximum number of times to retry a task for this transform after a task run fails.

nested_items.name: TransformEncryption
nested_items.description: The encryption-at-rest settings of the transform that apply to accessing user data. Machine learning transforms can access user data encrypted in Amazon S3 using KMS.

nested_items.name: MlUserDataEncryption
nested_items.description: An MLUserDataEncryption object containing the encryption mode and customer-provided KMS key ID.

nested_items.name: MlUserDataEncryptionMode
nested_items.description: The encryption mode applied to user data. Valid values are:
DISABLED: encryption is disabled.
SSEKMS: use of server-side encryption with Key Management Service (SSE-KMS) for user data stored in Amazon S3.

nested_items.name: KmsKeyId
nested_items.description: The ID for the customer-provided KMS key.

nested_items.name: TaskRunSecurityConfigurationName
nested_items.description: The name of the security configuration.
